thread.title: Ikea to introduce living wage for all staff from next April
thread.title_full: Ikea to introduce living wage for all staff from next April

author: Elizabeth Anderson
title: Ikea to introduce living wage for all staff from next April
text:
Retail and Consumer Ikea to introduce living wage for all staff from next April The new hourly rate - which will be between £7.85 and £9.15 per hour - will apply to staff of all ages Ikea has 18 stores in the UK Photo: REX FEATURES 
Swedish retail giant Ikea has announced it will adopt the Government’s new living wage from April 1 next year. 
The company said the move would affect 50pc of its 9,000 workers in the UK. 
It means that all Ikea employees across the UK, not just those over 25, will receive a minimum of £7.85 per hour and £9.15 per hour within London by 2016. 
Chancellor George Osborne announced in the recent summer Budget that he would introduce a new national living wage for workers in the UK. From next April, firms will have to pay all workers aged over 25 at least £7.20 an hour – compared with £6.50 now – and this will rise to £9 by 2020. 
Ikea is one of the first retailers to commit to raising the minimum hourly rate it pays its British staff ahead of government guidelines. 
“Introducing the living wage is not only the right thing to do for our co-workers, but it also makes good business sense. This is a long-term investment in our people based on our values and our belief that a team with good compensation and working conditions is in a position to provide a great experience to our customers,” said Gillian Drakeford, country manager for Ikea UK and Ireland. 
Ikea has introduced a number of programmes to reward staff in the past couple of years. 
Under a programme called “Tack!”– Swedish for thanks – staff who have been in their roles for at least five years receive an annual top-up to their pension if the business hits global sales targets. 
It has also paid out millions of euros in bonuses to staff after growing its business in Asia and Europe. 
The living wage makes good business sense, says Ikea boss Gillian Drakeford 
Ikea, which has had a presence in the UK since 1987, revealed in April that pre-tax profits had fallen by 10pc to £41.8m in the year to August, due to investments in its staff loyalty programmes and because of a new series of price cuts for customers. 
The group has 18 stores in the UK, and had planned to open four more this year, although this is now looking unlikely because of planning difficulties. 
Ikea plans to boost global sales to €50bn (£35bn) by 2020.
